snippet.textDisplay:
I hated Unicorn. I really really hate Unicorn. As a longtime fan of the UC era, specifically the One Year War and Stardust Memory, and a lot of more stuff.
Unicorn was a big fat slap to the face to everyone who loved UC. Oh it was typical and classic up until the final episode where the truth about the Laplace Box was released and it was just... So fucking stupid beyond human comprehension. And Origin, fucking Origin - also known as " look how awesome Char is! "- the anime. What a joke. Every character has the same face and the timeline gets completely raped apart by the introduction of GUNTANK, YEARS BEFORE IT WAS EVER A THING.

And then Thunderbolt.. Fucking Thunderbolt..
Or as I'd like to call it " Bandai's continual redemption of Zeon THE SPACE NAZIS while assholifying the Earth Federation more ". I get really fucking uncomfortable with the thought of how much they are humanizing the Zeon side and demonizing the Earth Federation when we consider that GIHREN IS A THING and we KNOW what Zeon all are. Like really, it's a new constant trend where they keep making EF the biggest dicks ever while making Zeon just " misunderstood " and " good ".

- picks up a Megaphone - You're hardly good when you're responsible for killing over Half of Earth's population on your own, and gassing your own people in the famous 2 second warning.

But noo, noo noo. Let's paint EF as the BAD GUYS!

Just.. Ugh..

I took one look at Darlin' in the Franxxx, thought the mecha design were pretty neat.
Then I saw how the Piloted it and I refused to EVER watch that piece of shit.

No, I'll stick with the old school.
snippet.textOriginal:
I hated Unicorn. I really really hate Unicorn. As a longtime fan of the UC era, specifically the One Year War and Stardust Memory, and a lot of more stuff.
Unicorn was a big fat slap to the face to everyone who loved UC. Oh it was typical and classic up until the final episode where the truth about the Laplace Box was released and it was just... So fucking stupid beyond human comprehension. And Origin, fucking Origin - also known as " _look how awesome Char is!_ "- the anime. What a joke. Every character has the same face and the timeline gets completely raped apart by the introduction of GUNTANK, YEARS BEFORE IT WAS EVER A THING.

And then Thunderbolt.. Fucking Thunderbolt..
Or as I'd like to call it " _Bandai's continual redemption of Zeon THE SPACE NAZIS while assholifying the Earth Federation more_ ". I get really fucking uncomfortable with the thought of how much they are humanizing the Zeon side and demonizing the Earth Federation when we consider that *GIHREN IS A THING* and we KNOW what Zeon all are. Like really, it's a new constant trend where they keep making EF the biggest dicks ever while making Zeon just " _misunderstood_ " and " _good_ ".

- _picks up a Megaphone_ - You're hardly good when you're responsible for killing over Half of Earth's population on your own, and gassing your own people in the famous 2 second warning.

But noo, noo noo. Let's paint EF as the BAD GUYS!

Just.. Ugh..

I took one look at Darlin' in the Franxxx, thought the mecha design were pretty neat.
Then I saw how the Piloted it and I refused to EVER watch that piece of shit.

No, I'll stick with the old school.

snippet.textDisplay: All I like out of Mecha anime is just Gundam. Everything else just seems way too cartoony with magical powers and skinny machines that don't even look right for fiction. Its just not that interesting seeing mechs fight with swords and shit when actual humans in plenty of other anime can father than a semi-realistic take in akin to titles like Macross, Gundam, and Patlabor. Alongside that I'm pretty tired of these generic main characters the anime/manga industry keeps peddling in these newer series.
snippet.textOriginal: All I like out of Mecha anime is just Gundam. Everything else just seems way too cartoony with magical powers and skinny machines that don't even look right for fiction. Its just not that interesting seeing mechs fight with swords and shit when actual humans in plenty of other anime can father than a semi-realistic take in akin to titles like Macross, Gundam, and Patlabor. Alongside that I'm pretty tired of these generic main characters the anime/manga industry keeps peddling in these newer series.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm sure this is probably some huge sin of an idea and know too well it would get fucked up some how. But in this day and age where CG fairly common and starting to look decent while some people are sick of the same old thing, why not take some mech video games and make shows out of them? And not like a repeat of 80s Battletech TV show, though It would be cool if we had a BT/MW show that stuck close to the original material and tried to stay serious and WASN'T a total scam done by PGI....yeah I'm looking at you MW5. But yeah, I know it's usually a bad idea to make movies/shows out of videogames, but as something different then the norm why not try and make a new Battletech, or a Armored Core or something like that? You could pair them with new released games and provide something that is different than the stereotypical Japanese flashy colorful mech which may be more appealing to a wider audience. Just....for the love of all things sacred, DO NOT add ANY forms of overused cute, silly or sexy tropes, just....don't. If your going to make a show based off a serious and dark franchise like Armored Core or Battletech do not do it, yes I know Battletech has sex appeal but there's a huge difference between 80s pinups and that girl who always winds up tripping and falling on some guy then beating the snot out of him because her tit landed in his hand but if your going to do that do it with a franchise that it wouldn't be completely out of place in.



Though on the flip side of that mech games are suffering the same problem and I can't remember who exactly but I remember someone at HBS (the guys behind the new battletech game who are run by the founder of battletech) was interveiwed and was quoted saying that mecha is just falling out of popularity as a whole, I guess it's just kinda gone the same route as westerns, over used and everyone's burnt out.
snippet.textOriginal:

And not like a repeat of 80s Battletech TV show, though It would be cool if we had a BT/MW show that stuck close to the original material and tried to stay serious and WASN'T a total scam done by PGI....yeah I'm looking at you MW5. But yeah, I know it's usually a bad idea to make movies/shows out of videogames, but as something different then the norm why not try and make a new Battletech, or a Armored Core or something like that? You could pair them with new released games and provide something that is different than the stereotypical Japanese flashy colorful mech which may be more appealing to a wider audience. Just....for the love of all things sacred, DO NOT add ANY forms of overused cute, silly or sexy tropes, just....don't. If your going to make a show based off a serious and dark franchise like Armored Core or Battletech do not do it, yes I know Battletech has sex appeal but there's a huge difference between 80s pinups and that girl who always winds up tripping and falling on some guy then beating the snot out of him because her tit landed in his hand but if your going to do that do it with a franchise that it wouldn't be completely out of place in.  



Though on the flip side of that mech games are suffering the same problem and I can't remember who exactly but I remember someone at HBS (the guys behind the new battletech game who are run by the founder of battletech) was interveiwed and was quoted saying that mecha is just falling out of popularity as a whole, I guess it's just kinda gone the same route as westerns, over used and everyone's burnt out.

snippet.textDisplay: I believe that the show that encapsulated the decline of Mecha was RoosterTeeth's Gen:Lock. GL was written as a mad-libs of mecha tropes with a lack of any real originality and felt more like a weeaboo's take on Mecha than an actual western take on the mecha sub-genre (TitanFall, Megas XLR, BattleTech). There's a reason why many RT fans have mockingly called it Gen:eric.
snippet.textOriginal: I believe that the show that encapsulated the decline of Mecha was RoosterTeeth's Gen:Lock. GL was written as a mad-libs of mecha tropes with a lack of any real originality and felt more like a weeaboo's take on Mecha than an actual western take on the mecha sub-genre (TitanFall, Megas XLR, BattleTech). There's a reason why many RT fans have mockingly called it Gen:eric.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't know, maybe because of the reasons that I watch from a video youtube about the fall of mecha anime:

1. Social change: Fewer and fewer people longer care about big war with badass battle sequense because war become more and more at the back og people's mind. ( And in a way it make sense, we are currently live in the longest peace time period compare to the previous generation. Local conflict yes, back breaking attrition WW2 style war no )

2. Toy sale, people nowaday attract morr with waifu figma than mech model ( I remember a quote where the narrator said that Gundam isn't bringing the most profit for Sunrise, it's Love Live , an Idol franchise ).

snippet.textDisplay:
All of anime, not just mecha, currently lacks grit in my humble opinion. Morales and values have changed drastically.

As a fan I would really like someone to pass out a whole bunch of John Wayne, and Clint Eastwood movies for writers and illustrators to draw from. They would probably throw them in the trash though.

Mecha Anime needs more Stardust Memory, 08th MS Team, Trigun, Outlaw Star and Bebop influenced series.

Everything new now just seems like .hack sign version 2.0. Which is disgusting to me, but marvelous to others.

At the end of the day you gotta keep the lights on and appeal to as many people as possible. I get that. However, there used to be a way to be tough, and gritty, and mean! With an emphasis on Mercy and kindness. I want that. I miss that. Without it we get.... What we have now. I believe that this current state is simply the curse of Evangelion.
snippet.textOriginal:
All of anime, not just mecha, currently lacks grit in my humble opinion.  Morales and values have changed drastically. 

As a fan I would really like someone to pass out a whole bunch of John Wayne, and Clint Eastwood movies for writers and illustrators to draw from. They would probably throw them in the trash though.

Mecha Anime needs more Stardust Memory, 08th MS Team, Trigun, Outlaw Star and Bebop influenced series. 

Everything new now just seems like .hack sign version 2.0. Which is disgusting to me, but marvelous to others. 

At the end of the day you gotta keep the lights on and appeal to as many people as possible. I get that. However, there used to be a way to be tough, and gritty, and mean! With an emphasis on Mercy and kindness. I want that. I miss that. Without it we get.... What we have now. I believe that this current state is simply the curse of Evangelion.

snippet.textDisplay:
everyone misses the point... How Japan choose their storyline and genre.

2019:
is a year of interchange era between old to new revolutions. That's why isekai exist = To live in a new world.


2020:
New Revolutions, IOT and Society 5.0. All genre following these steps. More futuristic anime. more dive in Anime. Since, robotics is the old revolutions for japan. While dive in will became a new item in future.

You can see how SAO became the main thing even there is people dislike it because it uses soul translator.


Gundam war turns to Gundam Builder but Dive in function ( yet still war, but they realised it not just a game).


You may realise if you follow all Japan franchised film such as Kamen Rider. When Zi-O is referred to as the end of the old era. Build Interchange Era. While zero-One is the new revolutions of futuristics technology.

You can see how SAO became the main thing even there is people dislike it because it uses soul translator.

snippet.textDisplay: I might be a little biased, but gritty, somewhat realistic “war of attrition” mecha anime is my favorite. My first anime was Aldnoah.Zero and my second was Gundam IBO. By this point I’m die hard Gundam. I watch the anime, buy the gunpla, and play the games. I really think an Origin style remake of the 79 OVA would make it really easy for interested anime watchers to get into the Goliath of mecha and the rest of the genre from there.
snippet.textOriginal: I might be a little biased, but gritty, somewhat realistic “war of attrition” mecha anime is my favorite. My first anime was Aldnoah.Zero and my second was Gundam IBO. By this point I’m die hard Gundam. I watch the anime, buy the gunpla, and play the games. I really think an Origin style remake of the 79 OVA would make it really easy for interested anime watchers to get into the Goliath of mecha and the rest of the genre from there.

snippet.textDisplay: Mecha has not changed... Gigguk has changed; like most of us.   Most of the Mecha series that are beloved now had serious problems in plot and pacing... but because it was new to the taste we overlooked the last 2 episodes of Evangelion or table kun of Code G, or even the firepower issues in Full Metal Panic.  Now as older and more discerning we get upset with plot holes and  silly twists.  I actually liked Guilty Crown even with the problems. I enjoyed the art and style of Darling in the Franxx enough to get past the change in enemies issue.
snippet.textOriginal: Mecha has not changed... Gigguk has changed; like most of us.   Most of the Mecha series that are beloved now had serious problems in plot and pacing... but because it was new to the taste we overlooked the last 2 episodes of Evangelion or table kun of Code G, or even the firepower issues in Full Metal Panic.  Now as older and more discerning we get upset with plot holes and  silly twists.  I actually liked Guilty Crown even with the problems. I enjoyed the art and style of Darling in the Franxx enough to get past the change in enemies issue.

snippet.textDisplay:
Mecha early in the decade slowly became a boring genre.


Earlier Gundam series of the decade were action packed and the story stilted. And we had transition of Gundam 00 where the story is good and the action scene acceptable. Then we get Gundam Iron and Blood where the story started good but lacking in action then the story just got stupid.


Aldionah and the other mecha series started out strong story wise and action scene pacing. But a lot of the Mecha series fell in the "talking jutsu" episodes. Like why watch Mecha anime if all I'm getting is talking and floating robots? I hope I'm not the only one who noticed that a lot of Mecha series have their robots just flying, floating, or just background objects. Like really why make a Mecha anime show just to spend so much time not showing the robots? Where is the balance?
snippet.textOriginal:
Mecha early in the decade slowly became a boring genre.  


Earlier Gundam series of the decade were action packed and the story stilted.  And we had transition of Gundam 00 where the story is good and the action scene acceptable.  Then we get Gundam Iron and Blood where the story started good but lacking in action then the story just got stupid.


Aldionah and the other mecha series started out strong story wise and action scene pacing.  But a lot of the Mecha series fell in the "talking jutsu" episodes.  Like why watch Mecha anime if all I'm getting is talking and floating robots?  I hope I'm not the only one who noticed that a lot of Mecha series have their robots just flying, floating, or just background objects.  Like really why make a Mecha anime show just to spend so much time not showing the robots?  Where is the balance?

snippet.textDisplay:
Looking at the New Hotness of Isekai, it looks like we would need a mecha anime that subverts the trope. But looking at the 3 Isekai that really stood out as anything other than SAO clones, we did a few of those same things with Gundam: we had lighthearted Slime-esque series in the SD and Gundam Build series and the closest we really came to Overlord-level villain protagonist was SEED Destiny.

Even subverting tropes doesn’t seem to work, like how we had the underrated Break Blade OVA subvert the magical hero trope. Hell, we had a mecha isekai with Knights & Magic that sadly had FMA Disorder. Unless we get a Transformers series that isn’t ashamed of its human element I don’t see too many brand-new directions we can go...
snippet.textOriginal:
Looking at the New Hotness of Isekai, it looks like we would need a mecha anime that subverts the trope. But looking at the 3 Isekai that really stood out as anything other than SAO clones, we did a few of those same things with Gundam: we had lighthearted Slime-esque series in the SD and Gundam Build series and the closest we really came to Overlord-level villain protagonist was SEED Destiny.

Even subverting tropes doesn’t seem to work, like how we had the underrated Break Blade OVA subvert the magical hero trope. Hell, we had a mecha isekai with Knights & Magic that sadly had FMA Disorder. Unless we get a Transformers series that isn’t ashamed of its human element I don’t see too many brand-new directions we can go...

snippet.textDisplay:
I would argue anime itself becoming mainstream was what killed mecha. Yes there were some good mechas in the 2000s and I would argue Gundam Blood Orphans was very good( season 1 that is) but now modern anime watchers cannot be bothered to watch mecha as giant robots are more of a niche than "WOW GIANT ROBOTS".Also I would argue storyboards and scripts in anime has tanked since 2010. Kill La Kill had a very good and heartwarming story from start to finish that was consistent. Darling in the Franx just focused too much on Hiro who was more of a self insert than a character, even Shinji in EVA had his own iconic personality, Jesus Yamato(Gundam Seed) and Simon(Guren Lagann) too. I think Japan just needs to have a decent plot with characters that feel like people and not anime troupes. Troupes are nice to form a base but not good when your entire story depends on them.
Another example but separate genre, in FATE Unliminited Bladeworks, Shiro's saviour complex was a plotline that was delved into, torn about, criticized and debated, something almost every protagonist has today and it was pointed out to be very unhealthy( at least in that universe but generally this should be the case more/less) so I just think Mecha should do something like a Reconnaissance again along those lines.
snippet.textOriginal:
I would argue anime itself becoming mainstream was what killed mecha. Yes there were some good mechas in the 2000s and I would argue Gundam Blood Orphans was very good( season 1 that is) but now modern anime watchers cannot be bothered to watch mecha as giant robots are more of a niche than "WOW GIANT ROBOTS".Also I would argue storyboards and scripts in anime has tanked since 2010. Kill La Kill had a very good and heartwarming story from start to finish that was consistent. Darling in the Franx just focused too much on Hiro who was more of a self insert than a character, even Shinji in EVA had his own iconic personality, Jesus Yamato(Gundam Seed) and Simon(Guren Lagann) too. I think Japan just needs to have a decent plot with characters that feel like people and not anime troupes. Troupes are nice to form a base but not good when your entire story depends on them.
Another example but separate genre,  in FATE Unliminited Bladeworks, Shiro's saviour complex was a plotline that was delved into, torn about, criticized and debated, something almost every protagonist has today and it was pointed out to be very unhealthy( at least in that universe but generally this should be the case more/less) so I just think Mecha should do something like a Reconnaissance again along those lines.
